text:
What is the history of how julia ends up with `isequal` and `==`
I assumed everyone did it, but it turns out every language i can find just has pathological behavour if you put a nan in a dictionary.
I think maybe Racket doesn’t, not sure though

elements.text: What is the history of how julia ends up with

I assumed everyone did it, but it turns out every language i can find just has pathological behavour if you put a nan in a dictionary.
I think maybe Racket doesn’t, not sure though

text: I think for us it came from half wanting to follow IEEE 754 and half wanting a more "sane" equality operator. Java also has both

elements.text: I think for us it came from half wanting to follow IEEE 754 and half wanting a more "sane" equality operator. Java also has both

text:
What does java call them?
Java's floats are weird because they are not object unlike everything elae

elements.text:
What does java call them?
Java's floats are weird because they are not object unlike everything elae

text:
```jshell> var f = new Float(Float.NaN)
f ==> NaN

jshell> f.equals(Float.NaN)
$34 ==> true

jshell> Float.NaN == Float.NaN
$35 ==> false```

elements.text:
jshell> var f = new Float(Float.NaN)
f ==> NaN

jshell> f.equals(Float.NaN)
$34 ==> true

jshell> Float.NaN == Float.NaN
$35 ==> false

text: Java has autoboxing so it just wraps primitives into objects automatically

elements.text: Java has autoboxing so it just wraps primitives into objects automatically
